newsitem.title: BRAZIL: CPFL says groups picked to advise on sale.
newsitem.headline: CPFL says groups picked to advise on sale.

text.p: Sao Paulo state power utility Companhia Paulista de Forca e Luz (CPFL) said two groups have apparently won contracts to advise on its planned privatization.

A CPFL spokesman said a consortium of Trevisan, Arthur D. Little, BFB and Banco Liberal beat two other competitors to carry out an economic and financial evaluation of the firm and suggest a minimum sale price.

He added a group made up of Maxima, Morgan Stanley, SBC Warburg and Banco Omega also scored highest out of eight groups vying for a broader contract to recommend as privatization model as well as conduct the financial study and suggest a base price.
So-called A and B service contracts, which give the consortia 120 days to complete work, have not been signed yet, the spokesman said.
Losing bidders have five days to appeal and an injunction has been granted by a Campinas court preventing the formal granting of the contracts.
CPFL, the jewel of the state's electrical sector, is expected to be sold off by October, in the first selloff in Sao Paulo's privatization program.
